Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


CENSUS  OF  IKELAND,  1911.


COUNTY  OF  ANTEim.


In  addition  to  the  information  contained  in  the  County  Tables,  it  has  been  deemed  advisable  to  adopt  the
course  {pursued  in  previous  Censuses,  and  give  the  following  Summary  of  the  results  obtained  respecting  the
(Administrative)  County  of  Antrim,  from  the  Census  Eeturns  of  1911.


SUMMARY.

Area. — The  (Administrative)  County  of  Antrim  covers  an  area  of  752,689  statute  acres,  or  3-6  per
cent,  of  the  total  area  of  the  country.

Population  (Table  II.). — The  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Antrim  according  to  the  Census  of
1901,  was  196,090  ; and  according  to  the  recent  Census.  193,864  (93,651  Males  and  100,213  Females),  or
1'14  per  cent,  less  than  in  1901.

County  Districts  (Table  VI.). — The  following  Statement  shows,  by  County  Districts  (as  constituted
under  the  Local  Government  (Ireland)  Act,  1898),  the  number  of  persons  in  1901  and  1911,  and  the  increase
or  decrease  during  the  decade  : —


County  Districts.

Population.

Increase  oi'  Decrease  between
1901  and  1911.

1911.

From  the  foregoing  Statement  it  will  be  observed  that  there  was  an  increase  in  9 County  Districts,
ranging  from  29-5  per  cent,  iu  Ballyclare -Urban,  and  20-5  per  cent,  in  l^ame  Urban,  to  4-5  per  cent,  in
Ballymena  Urban,  and  0-5  per  cent,  in  Lisburn  Rural;  but  a decrease  in  6 County  Districts,  the  highest
percentage  of  decrease  being  in  Ballymena  Rural,  viz.,  12'2  per  cent.,  and  the  lowest  in  Antrim  Rural,  viz.,
0-7  per  cent.

Families  and  Houses  (Table  VIII.).— The  number  of  distinct  Families  in  the  County  at  the  time  of  the
late  enumeration  was  41,872,  the  average  number  of  persons  in  a family  being  thus  4'6.  The  number  of
Inhabited  Houses  was  41,420,  showing  an  average  of  4 ' 6 persons  to  each  house.  In  calculating  these  averages
the  Special  Inmates  of  Public  Institutions  have  been  omitted.

Occupiers  of  less  than  5 Rooms  (Tables  IX.,  X.).— The  number  of  Occupiers  (or  Heads  of  Families)
m occupation  of  less  than  five  rooms  in  1911  was  25,449,  or  60'8  per  cent,  of  the  total  munber  of  Families
in  the  County,  and  of  these  1,331,  or  3'2  per  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families  in  the  County  were
occupiers  of  one  room  ; 8,429,  or  20-1  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  two  rooms  ; 7,574,  or  18-1  per  cent.,  occupiers
of  three  rooms  ; and  8,116,  or  19 '4  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  four  rooms.

The  number  of  Tenements  of  One  Room  in  the  County  was  1,331,  comprising  566  cases,  in  which  the
room  had  only  one  occupant ; 578  where  the  room  had  2,  3,  or  4 occupants  : 155  cases  in  which  there  were
5,  6,  or  7 occupants ; and  32  cases  where  the  occupants  exceeded  7 in  number,  including  3 cases  of  10
persons  in  the  room.

Civic  Areas.— Towns  having,  in  1911,  a population  of  2,000  and  upwards,  are  classified  as  Civic  Areas.
The  County  contains  seven  such  Areas,  viz.,  Ballyclare,  Ballymena,  Ballymoney,  Garrickfergus,  Larne,
Lisburn  and  Portrush.  In  1901  the  population  of  these  Areas  amounted  to  40  719  In  1911  it  was  44  989,
showing  ail  increase  of  4,270  persons,  or  10-5  per  cent. ; but  in  the  remainder  of  the  County  there  was  a
decrease  of  4-2  per  cent.


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


COUNTY  OF  ANTRIM.


VII.


Pauperism  (Table  XII.). — The  number  of  persons  returned  in  1901  as  receiving  relief  under  the  Poor
Law  System  was  3,098,  or  one  in  every  63  of  the  population  ; of  this  number  1,014  were  inmates  of  Work-
houses,  and  2,084  were  in  receipt  of  Outdoor  Relief.  In  1911  the  number  returned  was  2,465,  or  one  in
every  79  of  the  population ; 1,160  of  these  being  in  the  Workhouses,  and  1,305  on  Outdoor  Relief,  which
fiffure  includes  134  children  Boarded-out.

The  Sick  (Table  XII.).— In  1901  the  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Antrim  returned  as  Sick,
on  the  night  of  the  Census,  was  1,465,  or  one  in  every  134  of  the  population.  In  1911  the  number  so
returned  was  1,504,  or  one  in  every  129  of  the  population ; of  the  latter  number,  631  were  at  their  own  homes,
and  873  were  in  hospital.

Marriages,  Births,  and  Deaths  (Table  XIV.).— For  the  purposes  of  Registration  of  Births,  Deaths,  and
Marriages,  the  Poor  Law  Union  forms  a “ Superintendent  Registrar’s  District.”  Each  Union  or  Superintendent
Bepstrar’s  District  is  divided  into  Dispensary  Districts  for  the  Medical  Relief  of  the  Poor  under  the  Medical
Charities  Act ; these  Dispensary  Districts,  save  in  a few  instances,  are  identical  with  the  Registrars’  Districts.
Bach  Dispensary  District  is  composed  of  a certain  number  of  District  Electoral  Divisions.

According  to  the  returns  of  the  Registrar-General,  the  number  of  marriages  registered  in  the  County  of
Antrim  during  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  1911,  was  10,528,  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate  of  5 4
per  1,000  of  the  population.  The  number  registered  in  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the  same  period  aSords
an  average  annual  rate  of  5'1  per  1,000.

The  number  of  Births  registered  in  the  County  during  the  ten  years  was  46,022,  affording  an  average
annual  rate  of  23'6  per  1,000  of  the  population,  the  average  yearly  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the
same  period  being  23‘1  per  1,000.

The  Deaths  registered  during  the  decennium  amounted  to  33,236,  being  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate
of  17‘1  per  1,000  ; the  corresponding  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  was  17'3  per  1,000.

Birthplaces  of  the  Inhabitants  (Table  XXV.).— Of  the  persons  enumerated  in  the  County  in  1911,  88;6
per  cent,  were  born  therein  ; 7 5 per  cent,  in  other  Counties  of  the  Province  of  Ulster  ; 0 • 5 per  cent,  in
Leinster;  0'2  per  cent,  in  Munster;  O' 2 per  cent,  in  Connaught;  2'5  per  cent,  in  Great  Britain , and
0'5  per  cent,  were  born  abroad.

Religious  Professions  (Table  XXIX.).— The  following  Statement  shows,  according  to  Religious  Professions,
the  Inhabitants  of  the  County  of  Antrim  in  1911 : —


Rei.igioos  Professions,

From  the  above  Table  it  will  be  seen  that,  of  the  total  population  of  the  County  in  1911,  20'5  per  cent,
were  Roman  Catholics  ; 21'7  per  cent.  Protestant  Episcopalians  ; 50'1  per  cent.  Presbyterians  ; and  2-0  per
cent.  Methodists.  In  1901  Roman  Catholics  formed  20 ' 6 per  cent. ; Protestant  Episcopalians,  20  • 9 per  cent. ;
Presbyterians,  50'8  per  cent. ; and  Methodists,  1'9  per  cent.,  of  the  population  of  the  County.

Education  (Tables  XXX.  and  XXXIU.).- In  reckoning  the  number  of  Hliterates  the  age  of  9 years
has  now  been  substituted  for  the  age  of  5 which  was  formerly  adopted.

On  this  basis  the  details  of  population,  aged  9 years  and  upwards,  for  this  County,  are:


Population,

9 years  and  upwards.

Numbers

[ Proportion  per  cent.

1 90-0

1 5'2

Total

157,812

1 100-

For  comparative  purposes  the  figures  for  those  between  the  ages  of  5 and  9,  who  can  read  and  write,  are
shown  in  Table  XXX.

It  is  satisfactory  to  note  that  had  the  earlier  age  of  five  been  taken  as  the  starting  point  on  this  occasion,
as  in  former  years,  it  would  have  appeared  that  the  per-centage  of  those  unable  to  read  or  write,  which  was
9 0 in  1891,  and  S'O  in  1901,  had  fallen  to  7'9  in  1911.


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


COUNTY  OF  ANTRIM.


Irish  Speaking  Population  (Tables  XXXVI.  and  XXXVII.).— The  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of
Antrim  returned  as  being  able  to  speak  the  Irish  Language  in  1911  was  2,724,  representing  1-4  per  cent,
of  the  total  population  of  the  County.

Table  XXXVI.  gives  for  the  first  time,  by  District  Electoral  Divisions,  the  information  available  regarding
the  Irish  Speaking  portion  of  the  population  ; while  Table  XXXVII.  shows,  by  County  Districts,  the  numbers
in  1911,  as  compared  with  those  returned  in  1901.

School  Attendance  (Table  XXXVIII.).— The  number  of  pupils  attending  school  in  the  County  of
Antrim,  according  to  the  Census  of  1901  (week  ending  11th  May),  was  31,746.  In  1911  the  number  returned
(for  week  ending  13th  May)  was  32,428.

Emigration  (Table  XLI.).— Tbe  number  of  Emigrants  dming  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  1911,
who  stated  that  they  were  from  the  County  of  Antiim  or  City  of  Belfast,  amounted  to  32,804  (18,707  males,
and  14,097  females)  ; the  number  for  the  decade  ending  31st  March,  1901,  was  14,946  ; for  that  ending  with
March,  1891,  45,469  ; for  that  ending  with  March,  1881,  59,431  ; for  that  ending  with  March,  1871,..
54,670,  and  for  that  ending  with  March,  1861,  77,516,  making  a total  of  284,836,  for  the  sixty  years.


WILLIAM  -T.  THOMPSON,

Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


CENSUS  OF  lEELAND,  1911.


CITY  (OR  COUNTY  BOROUGH)  OF  BELFAST.


In  addition  to  the  iuf()rmation  contained  in  the  County  Tables,  it  has  been  deemed  advisable  to  adopt  the
. course  pursued  in  previous  Censuses,  and  give  the  following  Summary  of  the  results  obtained  respecting  the
City  (or  County  Borough)  of  Belfast  from  the  Census  Eeturus  of  1911.


SUMMAEY.

Area.— The  City  (or  County  Borough)  of  Belfast  covers  an  area  of  15,139  statute  acres,  or  Ol  ner
cent,  of  the  total  area  of  the  country.  ^


The  number  of  persons  in  the  City  of  Belfast  according  to  the  Census  of
1901  was  349,180;  and  according  to  the  recent  Census,  386,947  (181,268  Males  and  205,679  Females),  or
10-82  per  cent,  more  than  m 1901.

Houses  (Table  VIII.).— The  number  of  distinct  Families  in  the  City  at  the
time  of  the  late  enummtion  was  77,370,  the  average  number  of  persons  in  a family  being  thus  4-9,  The
number  of  Inhabited  Houses  was  75,172,  showing  an  average  of  5'0  persons  to  each  house.'  In  calculating
these  averages  the  Special  Inmates  of  Public  Institutions  bave  been  omitted.

_ Occupiers  of  less  than  5 Rooms  (Tables  IX.,  X.). — The  number  of  Occupiers  (or  Heads  of  Families)
m occupation  of  less  than  five  rooms  in  1911  was  26.057,  or  33'7  per  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families
“ of  ^ese  2 were  occupiers  of  ])art  of  a room  only  ; 447  or  0'6  ])er  cent,  of  the  total  number

o 0^0^™  occupiers  of  one  room  ; 3,206,  or  4-2  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  two  rooms  •

3,898.  or  5'0  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  three  rooms ; and  18,505,  or  23'9  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  four  rooms.  '

The  number  of  Tenements  of  One  Room  in  the  City  was  448,  comprising  160  cases  in  which  the  room
had  only  one  occupant ; 254  where  the  room  had  2,  3,  or  4 occupants  ; 31  cases  in  which  there  were  5,  6,
or  7 occupants ; and  3 cases  where  the  occupants  exceeded  7 in  number.

T (Table  XII.).— Tbe  number  of  persons  returned  in  1901  as  receiving  relief  under  the  Poor

Law  bystem  was  3,629,  or  one  in  every  96  of  the  population  ; of  this  number  3,359  were  inmates  of
Workhouses,  and  270  were  in  receipt  of  Outdoor  Relief.  In  1911  the  number  returned  was  4,138
or  one  m every  94  of  the  population;  3,207  of  these  being  in  tbe  Workhouses,  and  931  on  Outdoor
Relief,  which  figure  includes  45  children  Boarded-out,  and  11  in  Certified  Schools.

The  Sick  (Table  XII.).— In  1901  tbe  number  of  persons  in  tbe  City  of  Belfast  returned  as  Sick,

o the  Census,  was  2,781,  or  one  m every  126  of  the  population.  In  1911  the  number  so  returned

was  2,873,  or  one  m every  135  of  the  population ; of  the  latter  number  674  were  at  their  own  homes,  and
3,199  were  in  bospitaJ.  ’

Marriages,  Births,  and  Deaths  (Table  XIV.).— For  the  purposes  of  Registration  of  Births,  Deaths  and
Marriages,  the  Poor  Law  Union  forra.s  a “ Superintendent  Registrar’s  District.”  Bach  Union  or  Superintendent
Registrar  s Distrujt  is  divided  into  Dispensary  Districts  for  the  Medical  Relief  of  the  Poor  under  the  Medical
Chanties  .^t ; th^  Dispenspy  D^tricts,  save  in  a few  instances,  are  identical  with  the  Registrars’
JJistriots.  Baoti  Dispensary  District  is  composed  of  a ceiiain  number  of  District  Electoral  Divisions.

According  to  tbe  returns  of  the  Registrar-General,  the  number  of  Marriages  registered  in  the  City  of
Belfast  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  1911,  was  27,861,  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate  of

7 6 per  1,000  of  the  popu  atioii.  The  number  registered  in  the  wliole  of  Ireland  during  the  same  period
affords  an  average  annual  rate  of  5-1  per  1,000.  ^ ^

The  number  of  Births  registered  in  the  City  during  the  ten  years  was  112,072,  affording  an  average

n(  iecmnmm  amounted  to  74,036,  being  equal  to  an  avoiage  annual  rate

ot  .iij  1 per  1,000  , the  correspoudmg  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  was  17'3  per  1,000.

From  the  above  Table  it  will  be  seen  that  of  the  total  population  of  the  City  in  1911,  21 1 per  vent,

Education  (Tables  XXX.  and  XXXIII.).— In  reckoning  the  number  of  illiterates  the  age  of  9 years  has

For  comparative  purposes  the  figures  for  those  between  the  ages  of  5 and  9,  who  can  read  and  write,
are  shown  in  Table  XXX.

It  is  satisfactory  to  note  that  had  the  earlier  age  of  five  been  taken  as  the  starting  point  on  this  occasion,
as  in  former  years,  it  would  have  appeared  that  the  per-centage  of  those  unable  to  read  or  write,  which  was
8'7  in  1891,  and7‘7  in  1901,  had  fallen  to  7'5  in  1911.

cent,  el  the  total  population  of  the  City.  Of  these  i could  speak  “ Irish  only,  and  7,691  could  speak  Irish
and  English.

regarding  the  Irish-speaking  portion  of  the  population ; while  Table  XXXV  . . . , yi

the  numbers  in  1911,  as  compared  with  those  returned  in  1901.

(for  week  ending  13th  May),  was  64,779.

with  March,  1891,  46,469  ; for  that  ending  with  March,  1881,  59,431 1 for  tliat  ending  1871,

54  670  and  for  that  ending  with  Match,  1861,  77,516,  making  a total  of  284,836  for  the  sixty  years.

[Province  or  Ulster.

area,  houses,

I'aule  VIII,— Showing,  by  Classes,  the  number  of  Houses  in  the  City  (or  County  Borough)  of  Belfast,  having  one  or
more  Families  residing  in  them,  and  the  number  of  Families  which  occupy  each  Class  of  Accommodation.


SUMMARY— NUMBER  OF  FAMILIES  WHICH  OCCUPY  EACH  CL.4SS  OF  ACCOMMODATION.


Note.— The  plao  of  closfullcntioa  in  the  foregoing  Table  ia  the  same  as  that  adopted  in  former  Censuses,  and  may  bs  thus  described
The  Talue  or  condition  of  a hoase,  ns  to  its  quality,  may  bo  considered  to  depend  mmnly  on—

1st,  Its  extent,  as  sliown  by  the  number  of  rooms  ; 2nd,  its  quality,  as  shown  by  the  number  of  its  windows,  and  3rd,  its  solidity  or  durability,  assboirn
by  tlic  material  of  its  walls  and  roof.  If  numbers  be  adopted  to  express  the  position  of  every  house  in  a scale  of  each  of  these  elements,
and  if  the  numbers  tlius  obtained  for  every  house  be  added  together,  a new  series  of  numbers  will  be  produced,  giving  the  position  of  each  house
in  a scale  compounded  of  ail  the  elements,  t.e.,  their  actual  state.

Four  classes  have  been  adopted,  and  the  msiilt  is,  that  in  the  lowest  of  the  four  classes  are  comprised  houses  principally  built  of  mud  or  otlier  perishable  material,
having  only  one  room  and  window  i in  the  third  a bettor  description  of  house,  varying  from  ouo  to  four  rooms  and  windows  ; in  the  second,  what  might
be  oonsidored  a good  farm  house,  having  from  five  to  nine  rooms  and  windows ; and  in  the  first  class  ail  houses  of  a hotter  description  than  the

The  accommodation  which  the  houses  affoi-d  has  also  been  arranged  under  four  classes,  viz. : —

First  Class  accommodation  consisting  of  1st  class  iiouses,  occupied  by  one  family.

Second  Class  accommodation  consisting  of  2nd  class  liouscs,  occupied  by  one  family,  or  of  1st  class  houses,  occupied  by  two  or  tliree  families.

Tliird  Class  accommodation  comprising  3rd  class  hoirses,  with  one  family  each,  or  2nd  class  houses,  with  two  or  throe  famiiies,  or  1st  class  houses
occupied  by  four  or  five  families.

Fourth  Class  accommodation  includes  all  tth  class  houses.  .3rd  class  houses  with  more  than  one  family,  2nd  class  houses  with  four  or  more  families,  and
1st  class  houses  inhabited  by  six  or  more  families.


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit

(n.)  Tbe  Civic  Areas  compiiae  all  Muiiicipal  Borouglis,  Urban  Districts,  and  Towns  of  2,000  inhabitants  and  upwards.

Note— Tlio  plan  of  classification  in  the  foregoing  Table  is  tlie  same  ns  that  adopted  in  forma-  Censuses,  and  may  be  thus  described:—

Tiic  value  or  condition  of  a house,  as  to  its  quolify,  may  be  considered  to  depend  inaiiJy  on—

1st.  Its  extent,  as  sliown  by  the  number  of  rooms ; 2nd,  ito  quoUty,  us  shown  by  the  number  of  its  windows,  and  3i-d,  its  sohdity  or  durabiUt,-.  as  sliowp
by  the  material  of  its  walls  and  roof.  If  numbers  be  adopted  to  express  the  position  of  every  house  in  a scale  of  each  of  these  elements,
and  if  the  numbers  thus  obtained  for  every  house  be  mlded  together,  a new  series  of  numbeis  wdl  be  produced,  giving  the  position  of  each  house
in  a scale  compounded  of  all  the  clcnionfs,  tlicir  actual  state.

Kour  classes  have  been  adopted,  and  the  i-csult  is,  that  in  the  lowest  of  the  fonrclasses  are  comprised  housespiincipallvbuiltofinudorothcr  perishable  luateris!
having  only  ono  room  and  window  ; in  tlie  third  a better  description  of  house,  varying  from  one  to  four  rooms'and  rvindows  ; in  tho  second  what  might
bo  considered  ft  good  farm  house,  having  from  five  to  nine  rooms  and  windows ; and  in  the  first  class  all  houses  of  a better  description  than  the

Tlie  accommodation  wliich  tho  Ileuses  afford  has  also  been  nrrauged  under  four  classes,  via,
h'irst  Class  accommodation  consisting  of  1st  class  houses,  occupied  by  one  family.

Second  aasa  accommodatjon  consisting  of  2nd  class  houses,  occupied  by  one  family,  or  of  1st  class  houses,  occupied  by  two  or  tliree  families.

Tliird  Class  accommodation  comprising  3rd  class  liouses,  with  one  family  each,  or  2nd  class  houses,  with  two  or  three  families  or  1st  class  bouses
oco^icd  by  four  or  five  families.

• Schools  in  which  n foreign  language  is  taught  haTe  been  eiaased  as  ‘‘  Superior  ” upon  the  assumed  likelihood  that  the  presence  of  a foreign  language  in  the
slocl  coarse  argues  a higher  standard  of  general  instruction  than  is  to  he  found  where  such  an  element  is  wanting.

cent. , but  m remainder  of  the  County  there  was  a decrease  of  3-6  per  cent.

Pauperism  (Table  XII.).— The  number  of  persons  returned  in  1901  as  receiving  relief  under  the  Poor
Law  System  was  1,256,  or  one  in  every  138  of  the  population ; of  this  number  631  were  inmates  of  Work-
houses  and  62o  were  in  receipt  of  Outdoor  Relief.  In  1911  the  number  returned  was  992,  or  one  in
every  1/0  of  the  population ; 588  of  these  beiug  111  the  Workhouses,  and  404  on  Outdoor  Relief,  which
figure  includes  37  children  Boarded-out.

The  Sick  (Table  XII.).— In  1901  the  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Donegal  returned  as  Sick,
on  the  night  of  the  Census,  was  998,  or  one  m every  174  of  the  population.  In  1911  the  number  so
returned  was  854,  or  one  in  every  1 97  of  the  population ; of  the  latter  number,  589  were  at  their  own  homes,
and  265  were  in  hospital.  ’

Marriages,  Births,  and  Deaths  (Table  XIV.). — For  the  purposes  of  Registration  of  Births,  Deaths,  and
llaiTiages,  the  Poor  Law  Union  forms  a “ Superintendent  Registrar’s  District.”  Each  Union  or  Superintendent
Registrar  s District  is  divided  into  Dispensary  Districts  for  the  Medical  Relief  of  the  Poor  under  the  Medical
Chanties  Act ; these  Dispensary  Districts,  save  in  a few  instances,  are  identical  ivith  the  Registrars’  Districts
Each  Dispensary  District  is  composed  of  a certain  number  of  District  Electoral  Divisions.

According  to  the  returns  of  the  Registrar-General,  the  number  of  marriages  registered  in  the  County  of

1 I®  was  7,570,  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate  of  4-4

per  1,000  of  the  population.  The  number  registered  in  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the  same  period  affords
an  average  annual  rate  of  5-1  per  1,000.


The  number  of  Births  registered  in  the  County  during  the  ten  yeai-s  was  38,098,  affording  an  average
annual  rate  of  22  ■ 3 per  1,000  of  the  population,  the  average  yearly  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the
same  period  beiug  23 -1  per  1,000.


The  Deaths  registered  diu'ing  the  decennium  amounted  to  26,437,  being  equal  to  au  average  annual  rate
of  15'4  per  1,000 ; the  corresponding  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  was  17'3  per  1,000.

Birthplaces  of  the  Inhabitants  (Table  XXV.). — Of  the  persons  enumerated  in  the  County  in  1911,  92-8
per  cent,  were  born  therein  ; 3‘6  per  cent,  in  other  Counties  of  the  Province  of  Ulster- ; O' 5 per  cent,  in
Leinster;  0-2  per  cent,  iu  Munster;  0-8  per  cent,  in  Connaught;  1-6  per  cent,  in  Great  Britain ; and
0-5  per  cent,  were  born  abroad.

Religious  Professions  (Table  XXIX.). — The  following  Statement  shows,  according  to  Religious  Professions,
the  Inhabitants  of  the  County  of  Donegal  in  1911 : —

From  the  above  Table  it  will  be  seen  that  of  the  total  population  of  the  County  in  1911,  78-9  per  cent,
were  Roman  Catholics  ; 10-7  per  cent.  Protestant  Episcopalians ; 8’9  per  cent.  Presbyterians  ; andl'Oper
cent.  Methodists.  In  1901  Roman  Catholics  formed  77 '7  per  cent. ; Protestant  Episcopalians,  11-6  per  cent. ;
Presbyterians,  9 '3  per  cent. ; and  Methodists,  1-1  per  cent.,  of  the  population  of  the  County.


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


COUNTY  OF  DONEGAL.


viii.


Education  (Tables  XXX.  and  XXXIII.). — In  reckoning  the  number  of  illiterates  the  age  of  9
has  now  been  substituted  for  the  age  of  5 which  was  formerly  adopted.

On  this  basis  the  details  of  population,  aged  9 years  and  upwards,  for  this  County,  are: —


Population,

9 yeai-s  aud  upwards.

Numbei-s

Proportion  per  cent.

Eead  and  Write  . .

102,619

74'6

Bead  only

6,586

, 4-8

Illiterate

28,346

1 20-6

Total

137,551

100-

For  comparative  purposes  the  figures  for  those  between  the  ages  of  5 and  9,  who  can  read  and  write  are
shown  in  Table  XXX.

. It  is  satisfactory  to  note  that  had  the  earlier  age  of  five  been  taken  as  the  stai'ting  point  on  this  occasiou,
as  in  former  years,  it  would  have  appeared  that  the  per-centage  of  those  unable  to  read  or  write,  which  ws«
31'1  in  1891,  and  26'0  in  1901,  had  fallen  to  22-6  in  1911.

Irish  Speaking  Population  (Tables  XXXVI.  and  XXXVII.). — The  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of
Donegal  returned  as  being  able  to  speak  the  Irish  Language  in  1911  was  59,313,  representing  35'2  per  cent
of  the  total  population  of  the  Coimty.  Of  these  4,733  could  speak  “ Irish  only”  and  54.680  could  speak
Irish  and  English.  ^

Table  XXXVI.  gives  for  the  fii-st  time,  by  District  Electoral  Divisions,  the  information  available  regardius
the  Irish  Speaking  portion  of  the  population  ; while  Table  XXXVII.  shows,  by  County  Districts,  the  numbers
in  1911,  as  compared  wdth  those  returned  in  1901.

School  Attendance  (Table  XXXVIII.). — The  number  of  pupils  attending  school  in  the  County  of
Donegal,  accordmg  to  the  Census  of  1901  (week  ending  11th  May),  was  18.196.  In  1911  the  number  returned
(for  week  ending  13th  May)  was  20,873.

Emigration  (Table  XLI.). — The  number  of  Emigrants  during  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March  1911,
who  stated  that  they  were  from  the  County  of  Donegal,  amounted  to  12,622  (6,018  males,  and  6 604  females)  ■
the  number  for  the  decade  ending  31st  March,  1901,  was  12,977  ; for  that  ending  with  March,  1891.  29,417  ;
for  that  ending  with  March,  1881,  30,085;  for  that  ending  with  March,  1871,  11.902  and  for  that
ending  w-ith  March,  1861,  38,260,  making  a total  of  135,263,  for  the  sixty  years.


WILLIAM  J,  THOMPSON,  •&gt;!

liegistrar-Gmeral.  I

EDWAE.D  O’FAREELL,  Oommissioneri^.

DANIEL  S.  DOYLE.  |

Census  Oeeice,

Chaklemont  House,  Dublin.
July,  1912.

Rural  Areas.


(«|  The  avic  Areas  comprise  aU  Municipal  Boroughs,  Urban  Districts,  aud  Towns  of
NoTE.-The  plan  of  classification  in  the  foregoing  Table  is  the  same  as  that  adopted
The  value  or  condition  of  a house,  as  to  ita  quality,  may  be  considered  to  depend  raai.
1st,  Its  extent,  as  shown  by  the  number  of  rooms ; 2nd,  its  quality,  as  showi
bv  the  material  of  its  walls  and  roof.  If  immbera  be  adopted  to  c.X]
and  if  the  numbers  thus  obtained  for  every  house  bo  added  together,  a ni
in  a scale  compounded  of  all  the  elements,  i.«.,  their  actual  state.

Four  classes  have  been  adopted,  and  the  result  is,  that  in  the  lowest  of  the  four  claasc
having  only  one  room  and  window ; in  the  third  a better  description  of  house
be  considered  a good  form  house,  liaviug  fi-om  five  to  nine  rooms  and  windoi
preceding.

' ‘he  houses  afford  has  also  been  arranged  under  four  classes,

iation  consisting  of  1st  class  liousss,  occupied  by  one  farm
lodation  consisting  of  2nd  class  houses,  occupied  by  one  I
idation  comprising  3rd  class  houses,  with  one  family  ea&lt;
r or  five  families.

odation  includes  all  4th  class  houses,  3rd  class  houses  witli


be  thus  described :

CENSUS  OF  lEELAND,  1911.


COUNTY  OP  DOWN.


In  addition  to  the  information  contained  in  the  County  Tables,  it  has  been  deemed  advisable  to  adopt  the
course  pursued  in  previous  Censuses,  and  give  the  following  Summary  of  the  results  obtained  respecting  the
(Administrative)  County  of  Down  from  the  Census  Returns  of  1911.

SUMMARY.

Area. — The  (Administrative)  County  of  Down  covers  an  area  of  609,239  statute  acres,  or  2-9  per
cent,  of  the  total  area  of  the  country.

Population  (Table  II.). — The  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Down,  according  to  the  Census
of  1901,  was  205,889  ; and  according  to  the  recent  Census,  204,303  (97,951  Males  and  106,352  Females),
or  0'77  per  cent,  less  than  in  1901.

County  Districts  (Table  VI.). — The  following  Statement  shows,  by  County  Districts  (as  constituted
under  the  Local  Government  (Ireland)  Act,  1898),  the  number  of  persons  in  1901  and  1911,  and  the  increase
or  decrease  during  the  decade  : —


* Formerly  Banbticlge,  Xo.  1.  t Formerly  Belfast,  No.  2.  J Formerly  Lisburn,  No.  2.

§ Formerly,  Lurgan  No.  2.

From  the  foregoing  Statement  it  will  be  observed  that  there  was  an  increase  in  11  County  Districts
ranging  from  28  6 per  cent,  in  Bangor  Urban,  and  23'9  per  cent,  in  Castlereagh  Rural,  to  0*8  per  cent,  in
Downpatrick  Rural  and  0^7  per  rent,  in  Newtownards  Rural;  but  a decrease  in  6 County  Districts,  the
highest  percentage  of  decrease  being  in  Banbridge  Rural,  viz.,  6'8  per  cent. , and  the  lowest  in  N ewry
Urban,  viz.,  3'6  per  cent.

Families  and  Houses  (Table  VIII.). — The  number  of  distinct  Families  in  the  County  at  the  time  of  the
late  enumeration  was  46,369,  the  average  number  of  persons  in  a family  being  thus  4‘  3.  The  number  of
Inhabited  Houses  was  46,114,  showing  an  average  of  4'4  persons  to  each  house.  In  calculating  these
averages  the  Special  Inmates  of  Public  Institutions  have  been  omitted.

Occupiers  of  less  than  6 Rooms  (Tables  IX.,  X.). — The  number  of  Occupiers  (or  Heads  of  Families)
in  occupation  of  less  than  five  rooms  in  1911  was  28,887,  or  62-3  per  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families
in  the  County,  and  of  these  2 were  occupiers  of  part  of  a room  only;  908,  or  2-0  per  cent.,  of  the  total
number  of  Families  in  the  County  were  occupiers  of  one  room  ; 9,758  or  21 -O  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  two
rooms  ; 10,660,  or  23-0  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  tliree  rooms ; and  7,559  or  16‘3  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  four
rooms.

The  number  of  Tenements  of  One  Room  in  the  County  was  909,  comprising  460  cases  in  which  the
room  had  only  one  occupant ; 353  where  the  room  had  2,  3,  or  4 occupants  ; 79  cases  in  which  there  were
5.  6,  or  7 occupants ; and  17  cases  where  the  occupants  exceeded  7 in  number,  including  2 cases  of  10
persons  in  the  room.

Civic  Areas. — Towns  having,  in  1911,  a population  of  2,000  and  upwards,  are  classified  as  Civic  .Areas.
The  County  contains  nine  such  Areas,  viz.,  Banbridge,  Bangor,  Donaghadee,  Dromore,  Holywood,
Newry,  Newtownards,  Downpatrick,  and  Comber.  In  1901  the  population  of  these  Areas  amounted  to
45,973.  In  1911  it  was  48,827,  showing  an  increase  of  2,854  persons,  or  6'2  per  cent.;,  but  in  the
remainder  of  the  County  there  was  a decrease  of  2-8  per  cent.

Pauperism  (Table  XII.). — The  number  of  persons  returned  in  1901  as  receiving  relief  under  the  Poor
Law  System  was  2,747,  or  one  in  every  75  of  the  population  ; of  this  number  753  were  inmates  of  Workhouses,
and  1,994  were  in  receipt  of  Outdoor  Relief.  In  1911  the  number  returned  was  1,756,  or  one  in  every  116
of  the  population  ; 557  of  these  being  in  the  Workhouses,  and  1,199  on  Outdoor  Relief,  which  figure
includes  95  children  Boarded-out.


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


COUNTY  OF  DOWN.


The  Sick  (Table  XII.). — In  1901  the  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Down  returned  as  Sick,
on  the  night  of  the  Census,  was  1,121,  or  one  in  every  184  of  the  population.  In  1911  the  number  so  returned
was  1 165.  or  o’re  in  every  175  of  the  population  ; of  the  latter  number  519  were  at  their  own  homes,  and
646  were  in  hospital.

Marriages,  Births,  and  Deaths  (Table  XIV.).— For  the  purposes  of  Registration  of  Births,  Deaths,  and
Marriages,  the  Poor  Law  Union  forms  a “ Superintendent  Registrar’s  District.”  Each  Union  or  Superintendent
Registrar’s  District  is  divided  into  Dispensary  Districts  for  the.  Medical  Relief  of  the  Poor  under  the  Medical
Charities  Act ; these  Dispensary  Districts,  save  in  a few  instances,  are  identical  with  the  Registrars’
Districts.  Each  Dispensary  District  is  composed  of  a certain  number  of  District  Electoral  Divisions.

According  to  the  returns  of  the  Registrar -General,  the  number  of  Marriages  registered  in  the  County
of  Down  during  the  ten  years  ending  Slst  March,  1911,  was  10,810,  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate
of  5-3  per  1,000  of  the  population.  The  number  registered  in  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the  same
period  affords  an  average  annual  rate  of  5- 1 per  1,000.

The  number  of  Births  registered  in  the  County  during  the  ten  years  was  46,629,  afiording  an  average
annual  rate  of  22-7  per  1,000  of  the  population,  the  average  yearly  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  during
the  same  period  being  23'1  per  1,000.

The  Deaths  registered  during  the  decennium  amounted  to  36,670,  being  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate
of  17-9  per  1,000;  the  corresponding  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  was  17'3  per  1,000.

Birthplaces  of  the  Inhabitants  (Table  XXV.).— Of  the  persons  enumerated  in  the  County  in  84-7
nercent  were  born  therein;  9-7  per  cent,  in  other  Counties  of  the  Province  of  Ulster ; 1 • 4 per  cent,
in  Leinster;  O' 3 per  cent,  in  Munster;  0-3  per  cent,  in  Connaught;  3-1  per  cent,  in  Great  Britain,


i be  seen  uhai  ui  Ihc  iuUl  of  the  County  in  1911,31-6  per  cent,

cent  Protestant  Episcopalians  ; 38-0  per  cent.  Presbyterians  ; and  2 2 per

2'  1 per  cent.,  of  the  population  of  the  County.

COUNTY  OF  DOWN.


Irish  Speaking  Population  (Tables  XXXVI.  and  XXXVII.). — The  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of
Down  returned  as  being  able  to  speak  the  Irish  Language  in  1911  was  2,432,  representing  1-2  per  cent,
of  the  total  population  of  the  County.

Table  XXXVI.  gives  for  the  first  time,  by  District  Electoral  Divisions,  the  information  available
regarding  the  Irish  Speaking  portion  of  the  population  ; while  Table  XXXVII.  shows,  by  County  Districts,
the  numbers  in  1911,  as  compared  with  those  returned  in  1901.

School  Attendance  (Table  XXXVIII.) — The  number  of  pupils  attending  school  in  the  County  of
Down,  according  to  the  Census  of  1901  (week  ending  11th  May),  was  3i,2o3.  In  1911  the  number
returned  (for  week  ending  13th  May),  was  33,617.

Emigration  (Table  XLI.). — The  number  of  Emigrants  during  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  1911
who  stated  that  they  were  from  the  County  of  Down,  amounted  to  15,709  (9,447  males,  and  6,262
females) ; the  number  for  the  decade  ending  31st  March,  1901,  was  7,837  ; for  that  ending  with  March.
1891,  23,633  ; for  that  ending  with  March,  1881,  31,132  ; for  that  ending  with  March,  1871,  28,270  and
for  that  ending  with  March,  1861,  47,906,  making  a total  of  154,492  for  the  sixty  years.


WILLIAM  J.  THOMPSON,

Registrar-General

EDWL4RD  0’EARE.ELL,

DANIEL  S.  DOYLE.

Families  and  Houses  (Table  VIII,).— The  number  of  distinct  Families  in  the  County  at  the  time  of  the
late  ennmCTation  was  13.973,  the  average  number  of  persons  in  a family  being  thus  4’4.  The  number  of
inhabited  Houses  was  13,674  showing  an  average  of  4 • 5 persons  to  each  house.  In  calculating  these  averages
the  bpecial  Inmates  of  Public  Institutions  have  been  omitted.

Occupiers  of  less  than  5 Rooms  (Tables  IX.,  X.).-The  number  of  Occupiers  (or  Heads  of  Families)
^ 9,484,  or  67'9  per  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families

tne  county,  and  of  these  523,  or  3'8  per  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families  in  the  County,  were
occupiers  of  one  room  ; 2,289,  or  16 '4  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  two  rooms  ; 4,375,  or 31 '3  percent.,  owupiers
of  three  rooms;  and  2,297,  or  16'4  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  four  rooms.

1 A 1 Tenements  of  One  Room  in  the  County  was  523,  comprising  270  cases,  in  which  the  room

had  only  one  occupant ; 204  where  the  room  had  2,  3,  or  4 occupants  ; 43  cases  in  which  there  were  5,  6,
01  I occupants  ; and  6 cases  where  the  occupants  exceeded  7 in  number,  including  one  case  of  10  persons.

Tl  . “''‘“/““S.-Towns  having,  in  1911,  a population  of  2,000  and  npwards,  are  classified  as  Civic  Areas.
ti  t “'I' Area  viz.,  Enniskillen  Uiban.  In  1901  the  population  of  this  Area  amounted

cf  +1  n'  l"  x.  \ i.847,  showing  a decrease  of  565  persons,  or  10-4  per  cent. ; in  the  remainder

ot  the  County  the  decrease  was  5-0  per  cent.

XII.).— The  number  of  persons  returned  in  1901  as  receiving  relief  under  the  Poor
oY7iqo  population  ; of  this  number  362  were  inmates  of  Workhouses,

th.  if  Tl-  of  Outdoor  Relief.  In  1911  the  number  returned  was  486.  or  one  in  every  127  of

cbbdS^Swlid^out^^  Workhouses,  and  214  on  Outdoor  Relief,  -which  figiue  includes  1&amp;


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


I


COUNTY  OF  FERMANAGH.


Vll.


The  Sick  (Table  XII.). — Ie  1901  the  Eumber  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Fermanagh  returned  as  Sick,
on  the  night  of  the  Census,  was  495,  or  one  in  every  132  of  the  population.  In  1911  the  number  so  retmn^
was  327,  or  one  in  every  189  of  the  population  ; of  the  latter  number  185  were  at  their  own  homes,  and  142
were  in  hospital.

Marriages,  Births,  and  Deaths  (Table  XIV.). — For  the  pui-poses  of  Registration  of  Births,  Deaths,  and
.Marriages,  the  Poor  Law  Union  forms  a “ Superintendent  Registrar’s  District.”  Each  Union  or  Superintendent
Register’s  District  is  divided  into  Dispensary  Districts  for  the  Medical  Relief  of  the  Poor  under  the  Medical
ChMities  Act ; these  Dispensary  Districts,  save  in  a few  instances,  are  identical  with  the  Registrars’  Districts.
Each  Dispensary  District  is  composed  of  a certain  number  of  District  Electoral  Divisions.

According  to  the  returns  of  the  Registrar-General,  the  number  of  marriages  registered  in  the  County  of
Fermanagh  dui'ing  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  1911,  was  2,908,  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate  of  4'6
per  1,000  of  the  population.  The  number  registered  in  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the  same  period  afiords
an  average  annual  rate  of  5 ' 1 per  1,000.

The  number  of  Births  registered  in  the  County  during  the  ten  years  was  13,305,  affording  an  average
annual  rate  of  20  9 per  1,000  of  the  population,  the  average  yearly  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the
same  period  being  23']  per  1,000.

The  Deaths  registered  during  the  decennium  amounted  to  10,366,  being  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate
of  16'3  per  1,000;  the  corresponding  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  was  17'3  per  1,000.

Birthplaces  of  the  Inhabitants  (Table  XXV.). — Of  the  persons  enumerated  in  the  County  in  1911,  85'8
per  cent,  were  born  therein ; 9'2  per  cent,  in  other  Counties  of  the  Province  of  Ulster ; I'l  per  cent,  in
Leinster  ; 0'4  per  cent,  in  Munster  ; 1'4  per  cent,  in  Connaught ; 1'7  per  cent,  in  Great  Britain  ; and  0'4
per  cent,  were  born  abroad.

Religious  Professions  (Table  XXIX.). — The  following  Statement  shows,  according  to  Religious  Professions,
the  Inhabitants  of  the  County  of  Fermanagli  in  1911 : —

From  the  above  Table  it  will  be  seen  that  of  the  total  population  of  the  County  in  1911,  56'2  per  cent,
were  Roman  Catholics  ; 34 '2  per  cent.  Protestant  Episcopalians  ; 2'0  per  cent.  Presbyterians  ; and  6'5  per
cent.  Methodists.  In  1901  Roman  Catholics  formed  55  ■ 3 per  cent. ; Protestant  Episcopalians,  35  ■ 3 per  cent. ;
Presbyterians,  2'0  per  cent. ; and  Methodists,  7'2  per  cent.,  of  the  population  of  the  County.

Education  (Tables  XXX.  and  XXXIII.). — In  reckoning  the  number  of  illiterates,  the  age  of  9 yeans
has  now  been  substituted  for  the  age  of  5,  which  was  formerly  adopted.

On  this  basis  the  details  of  population,  aged  9 years  and  upwards,  for  this  County,  ate  : —

For  comparative  purposes  the  figures  for  those  between  the  ages  of  5 and  9,  who  can  read  and  -write,  are
shown  in  Table  XXX.

It  is  satisfactory  to  note  that  had  the  earlier  age  of  five  been  taken  as  the  starting  point  on  this  occasion,
as  in  former  years,  it  would  have  appeared  that  the  per-centage  of  those  unable  to  read  or  write,  which  was
15'4  in  1891,  and  13'1  in  1901,  had  fallen  to  13'0  in  1911.

COUNTY  OF  FERMANAGH.


Irish  Speaking  Population  (Tables  XXXVI.  and  XXXVII.).— The  munber  of  persons  in  the  Coimtv  r,f
Fermanagh  returned  as  being  able  to  speak  the  Irish  Language  in  1911  was  1,563,  representine  2-.5  t,pt
of  the  total  population  of  the  Comity.  - &gt; F g ^ o per  cent.

Table  XXXVI.  gives  for  the  first  time,  by  District  Electoral  Divisions,  the  information  available  regarding
the  Irish  Speaking  portion  of  the  population  ; while  Table  XXXVII,  shows,  by  County  Districts,  the  numbers
in  1911,  as  compared  with  those  returned  in  1901.

School  Attendance  (Table  XXXVIII.). — The  number  of  pupils  attending  school  in  the  County  of
Fermanagh,  according  to  the  Census  of  1901  (week  ending  11th  May),  was  8,219.  In  1911  the  number  returned
(for  week  ending  13th  May)  was  8,827.

Emigration  (Table  XLI.).— The  number  of  Emigi'ants  during  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March  19li
who  stated  that  they  were  from  the  County  of  Fermanagh,  amounted  to  3,562  (1,886  males,  and  1,676  females)  ’
the  number  for  the  decade  ending  31st  March,  1901,  was  5,403 ; for  that  ending  with  March,  1891,  10  158  ’
for  that  ending  with  March,  1881,  10,514 ; for  that  ending  with  March.  1871,  10,864,  and  for  that  ending
with  March,  1861,  17,372,  making  a total  of  57,873,  for  the  sixty  year.s,  °

(o.)  Tho  CSvio  Areas  comprise  all  Municipal  Boroughs,  Urban  Districts,  and  Towns  of  2,000  inhabitants  and  upwards.

Note. — The  plan  of  classihcation  in  the  foregoing  Table  is  the  same  as  that  odcmted  in  former  Censuses,  and  may-  be  thus  described : —

Tho  ynlue  or  condition  of  a house,  as  to  its  quality,  may  be  considered  to  depemf  mainly  on —

1st,  Its  extent,  as  shown  by  tho  num’bsr  of  rooms  ; 2nd,  its  quality,  as  shown  by  the  number  of  its  windows,  and  3rd,  its  solidity  or  durability,  as  sliowi
by  the  material  of  its  walls  and  root  If  numbers  be  adopted  to  express  the  position  of  every  house  in  a scale  of  each  of  these  elemeots,
and  if  the  numbers  thus  obtained  for  every  house  he  added  together,  a new  series  of  numbers  will  be  produced,  giving  tho  position  of  each  ho«
in  a scale  compounded  of  all  tlie  elements,  t.e.,  then’  actual  state.

Four  classes  have  been  adopted,  and  the  result  is,  that  in  the  lowest  of  the  four  classes  are  comprised  houses  principally  built  of  mud  or  other  perishable

having  only  one  loom  and  window  ; in  the  third  a better  description  of  house,  varying  from  one  to  four  rooms  and  windows  ; in  the  seoooil,  what  oii|b
be  considered  a good  ftvrm  house,  having  from  five  to  nine  rooms  and  windows  ; and  in  the  first  class  all  houses  of  a hotter  description  tlian  tbi
preceding,

The  accommodation  which  tho  houses  afford  has  also  been  arranged  under  four  classes,  viz. ; —

First  Class  accommodation  consisting  of  1st  class  houses,  occupied  by  one  family.

Second  Class  accommodation  consisting  of  2nd  class  houses,  occupied  ^ one  family,  or  of  1st  class  houses,  occupied  by  two  or  three  families.

Third  Class  aocoinmodation  comprising  3rd  class  houses,  with  one  family  each,  or  2nd  class  houses,  with  two  or  tlu'oe  families,  or  1st  class  sou*
occupied  by  fortt  or  five  families.  ,

Fourth  Class  accommodation  includes  ell  4th  class  houses,  3rd  class  houses  with  more  than  one  family,  2nd  class  houses  with  four  or  more  families,

1st  class  houses  inhabited  by  six  or  more  fomihes.

CENSUS  OF  lEELAND,  1911


COTTNTY  AND  CITY  OF  LONDONDERKY.


In  addition  to  the  information  contained  in  the  County  Tables,  it  lias  been  deemed  advisable  to  adopt  the
course  pursued  in  previous  Censuses,  and  give  the  following  Summary  of  the  results  obtained  respecting  the
County  (Administrative)  and  City  of  Londondeiry  from  the  Census  Retunis  of  1911.


SUMMARY.

Area. — The  County  (Administrative)  and  City  of  Londonderry  covers  an  area  of  523,525  statute  acres,
or  2'5  per  cent,  of  the  total  area  of  the  country.

Population  (Table  II.). — The  number  of  persons  in  the  County  and  City  of  Londonderry  according  to
the  Census  of  1901  was  144,404 ; and  according  to  the  recent  Census,  110,625  (67,663  Males  and  72,962
Females),  or  2'62  per  cent,  less  than  in  1901.

County  Districts  (Table  VI.). — The  following  Statement  shows,  by  County  Distilcts  (as  constituted  under
the  Local  Government  (Ireland)  Act,  189S),  the  number  of  persons  in  1901  and  1911,  and  the  increase  or
decrease  during  the  decade : —


Popul  fttiou.

Inci'easc  or  Decrease
between  lOO'i  and  1911.

CooKTY  Districts.

1011.

Decrease.

Fi'om  the  foregoing  Statement,  it  will  be  observed  that  there  was  an  increase  of  2-2  per  cent,  in  London-
derry City,  and  of  1I'9  per  cent,  in  the  County  District  of  Coleraine  Urban  ; but  there  was  a decrease  in
each  of  the  other  County  Districts,  ranging  from  8'3  per  cent,  in  Limavady  Rural,  and  7'4  per  cent,  in
Maglierafelt  Rural  to  0'9  per  cent,  in  Limavady  Urban,  and  2'3  per  cent,  in  Coleraine  Rural.

Families  and  Houses  (Table  VIII.). — 1'he  number  of  distinct  Families  in  the  County  and  City  at  the
time  of  the  late  enumeration  was  29,860,  the  average  number  of  persons  in  a family  being  thus  4'6.  The
number  of  Inhabited  Houses  was  28,897,  showing  an  average  of  4'8  persons  to  each  house.  In  calculating
the.se  averages  the  Special  Inmates  of  Public  Institutions  have  been  omitted.

Occupiers  of  less  than  5 Rooms  (Tables  IX.,  X.). — The  number  of  Occupiers  (or  Heads  of  Families)
in  occupation  of  less  than  five  rooms  in  1911  waa  20,120,  or  67'4  per,  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families
ill  the  County  and  City,  and  of  these  6 were  occupiers  of  part  of  a room  only  ; 1,60!)  or  5’4  per  cent,  of  the
total  number  of  Families  in  the  County  and  City  were  occupiers  of  one  room  ; 7,137,  or  23'9  per  cent.,
occupiers  of  two  rooms  ; 5,789,  or  19'4  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  three  rooms ; and  5,579,  or  I8  7 pei'  cent.,
occupier'  of  four  rooms.

The  number  of  Tenements  of  One  Room  in  the  County  and  City  was  1,612,  comprising  572  cases  in  which
the  ro^nm  had  only  one  occupant ; 817  where  the  room  had  2,  3,  or  4 occupants  ; 181  cases  in  which  there
were  5,  6,  or  7 occupants ; and  42  cases  where  the  occupants  exceeded  7 in  number,  including  0 cases  of
10  persons,  2 cases  of  11  persons,  and  one  of  12  or  more  persons  in  the  room.

Civic  Areas. — Towns  having,  in  1911,  a population  of  2,000  and  upwards,  are  classified  as  Civic
Areas.  The  County  coLtains  3 such  Areas,  viz.,  Londonderry,  Coleraine,  and  Limavady.  In  1901  the
population  of  these  Area.s  amounted  to  49,542.  In  1911  it  was  51,232.  showing  an  increase  of  1,690
persons,  or  .)-4  per  cent. : but  in  the  remainder  of  the  County  there  was  a decrease  of  5'8  per  cent.


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


COUNTY  AND  CITY  OF  LONDONDEEEY.


vn.


Pauperism  (Table  XU.). — The  number  of  persons  returned  in  1901  in  the  County  and  City  as  receiving
relief  under  the  Poor  Law  System  was  1,096,  or  one  in  every  132  of  the  population ; of  this  number
690  were  inmates  of  Workhouses,  and  406  were  in  receipt  of  Outdoor  llelief.  In  1911  the  numbei'
returned  was  964  or  one  in  every  146  of  the  population ; 651  of  these  being  in  the  Workhouses,  and  313
on  Outdoor  Relief,  which  figure  includes  31  children  Boarded-out.


The  Sick  (Table  XII.). — In  1901  the  number  of  persons  in  the  County  and  City  of  Londonderry
returned  as  Sick,  on  the  night  of  the  Census,  was  709,  or  one  in  every  204  of  the  population.  In  Ivll  the
number  so  returned  was  772,  or  one  in  every  182  of  the  population ; of  the  latter  number  461  were  at
their  own  homes,  and  31]  were  in  hospital.

Marriages,  Births,  and  Deaths  (Table  XIV.). — For  the  purposes  of  Registration  of  Births,  Deaths,  and
Marriages,  the  Poor  Law  Union  forms  a “ Siiperintendent  Registrar’s  District.”  Bach  Union  or  Superintendent
Registrar’s  District  is  divided  into  Dispensary  Districts  for  the  Medical  Relief  of  the  Poor  under  the  Medical
Oh^ties  Act ; these  Dispensary  Districts,  save  in  a few  instances,  are  identical  with  the  Registrars’
Districts.  Each  Dispensary  District  is  composed  of  a certain  number  of  District  Electoral  Divisions.

According  to  the  returns  of  the  Registrai'-General,  the  number  of  Marriages  registered  in  the  County  and
City  of  Londonderry  during  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  1911,  was  7,979,  equal  to  an  average  annual
rate  of  5'6  per  1,000  of  the  population.  The  number  registered  in  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the  same
period  affords  an  average  annual  rate  of  5'1  per  1,000.

The  number  of  Births  registered  in  the  Count}'  and  City  during  the  ten  years  was  33,487,  affording
an  average  annual  rate  of  23'5  per  1,000  of  the  population,  the  average  yearly  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland
during  the  same  period  being  231  per  1,000.

The  Deaths  registered  during  the  deceunium  amounted  to  25,515,  being  equal  to  au  average  annual  rate
of  I7'9  per  1,000  ; the  corresponding  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  was  17‘3  per  1,000.


Birthplaces  of  the  Inhabitants  (Table  XXV.).  — Of  the  persons  enumerated  in  the  County  in  1911,88-6
per  cent,  were  born  in  the  County  or  City  of  Londonderry  ; 8'2  per  cent,  in  other  Counties  of  the  Province
of  Ulster ; 0’4  per  cent,  in  Leinster ; 01  per  cent,  in  Munster  ; 0 2 per  cent,  in  Connaught  ; P9  per  cent,
in  Great  Britain ; and  0'6  per  cent,  were  born  abroad.

Of  the  persons  enumerated  in  the  City  of  Londonderry  in  1911,  68  0 per  cent,  were  born  in  the  County
or  City  of  Londonderry  ; 22'7  per  cent,  in  other  Counties  of  the  Province  of  Ulster  ; L5  per  cent,  in  Leinster  ;
0-5  per  cent,  in  Munster ; 0 8 per  cent,  in  Connaught ; 5-8  per  cent,  in  Great  Britain  ; and  07  per  cent,
were  bom  abroad.

the  Inhabitants  of  the  County  and  City  of  Londonderry  in  1911

From  the  above  Table  it  will  be  seen  that  of  the  total  population  of  the  County  in  1911,  41-5  per  cent,
were  Roman  Catholics  ; 20'1  per  cent.  Protestant  Episcopalians  ; 34'3  per  cent.  Presbyterians  ; and  0'8  per
cent.  Methodists.  In  1901  Roman  Catholics  formed  4P4  per  cent. ; Protestant  Episcopalians,  19-G  per
cent. ; Presbyterians,  35'1  per  cent. ; and  Methodists,  07  per  cent,  of  the  population  of  the  County.

In  the  City  of  Londondeny,  according  to  the  present  Census,  56'2  per  cent,  of  the  populatioji  were
Roman  Catholics  ; 17'5  per  cent.  Protestant  Episcopalians ; 2P4  per  cent.  Presbyterians ; and  2'9  per  cent,
were  Methodists.  In  1901.  Roman  Catholics  formed  55'2  per  cent,  of  the  population;  Protestant
Episcopalians,  18  2 per  cent.  ; Presb}derians,  22'5  per  gent.  ; and  Methodists,  1 '8  per  cent,  of  the  population
of  the  City.

now  been  substituted  for  the  age  of  5 which  was  formerly  adopted.

For  comparative  purposes  the  figures  for  those  between  the  ages  of  5 and  9,  who  can  read  and  write


It  is  satisfactory  to  note  that  had  the  earlier  age  of  five  been  taken  as  the  starting  point  on  this  occasion
as  m former  years,  it  would  have  appeared  that  the  per-centage  for  the  Comity  and  City  of  those  unable  to
read  or  write,  which  was  14'3  in  1891,  and  11'.8  in  1901,  had  fallen  to  11-6  in  1911.  *

Irish  Speaking  Population  (Tables  XXXVI.  and  XXXVII.).-The  number  of  persons  in  the  County  and
City  of  Londoudevry  returned  as  being  able  to  speak  the  Irish  Language  in  1911  was  4,039,  representinu
2 9 per  cent,  of  the  total  population.  “ ^

Table  (XXXVI.)  gives  for  the  first  time,  by  District  Electoral  Divisions,  the  information  available
regarding  the  Irish-speakmg  portion  of  the  population;  while  Table  XXXVII.  shows  bv  Countv
Districts,  the  numbers  m 1911,  as  compared  with  those  returned  in  1901.  ’ ^

School  Attendance  (Table  XXXVIH.).— The  number  of  pupils  attending  school  in  the  County  and
City  of  Londonderry,  according  to  the  Census  of  1901  (week  ending  11th  May),  was  19  534  In  I9ii  the
number  returned  (for  week  ending  13th  May),  was  21,493.

Emigration  (Table  XLI.).— The  number  of  Emigi'ants  during  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March  1911
who  stated  that  they  were  from  the  County  and  City  of  Londonderry,  amounted  to  9,257  (5  095  males  and
noTof ’i  ^0^  the  decade  ending  31st  March,  1901,  was  8,152 ; for  that  ending  with  March,

f March.  1881.26,939;  for  that  ending  with  March,  1871,16  841  and

for  that  endmg  with  March,  1861,  27,738,  making  a total  of  112,126  for  the  sixty  years.

CENSUS  OF  lEELAND,  1911


COUNTY  OF  MONAGHAN.


In  addition  to  the  information  contained  in  the  County  Tables,  it  has  been  deemed  advisable  to  adopt  the
coui’se  pursued  in  previous  Censuses,  and  give  the  following  Summary  of  tlie  results  obtained  respectin&lt;^  the
(Administrative)  County  of  Monaghan  from  the  Census  Returns  of  1911.


SUMMARY.

Area. — The  (Administrative)  County  of  Monaghan  covers  an  area  of  319,889  statute  acres,  or  ]'5
per  cent,  of  the  total  area  of  the  country.

Population  (Table  II.).— The  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Monaghan,  according  to  the  Census
of  1901,  was  74,611  ; and  according  to  the  recent  Census,  71,455  (35,953  Males  and  35,502  Females)
or  4'23  per  cent,  less  than  in  1901.  ’

County  Districts  (Table  VI.). — The  following  Statement  shows,  by  County  Districts  (as  constituted
under  the  Local  Government  (Ireland)  Act,  1898),  the  number  of  persons  in  1901  and  1911,  and  the  increase
or  decrease  during  the  decade : —


County  District.?.

Population.

Increase  or  Decrease
between  1901  and  1911.

1911.

Increase.  Decrease.

From  the  foregoing  Statement  it  will  be  observed  that  there  was  an  increase  in  four  County  Districts^
viz.,  7'0  per  cent,  in  Carriclcmaoross  Urban,  7-4  per  cent,  in  Castleblayney  Urban,  16-1  per  cent,  in  Clones
Urban,  and  1 ■ 4 per  cent,  in  Monaghan  Urban  ; but  a decrease  in  each  of  the  remaining  County  Districts,
raiming  from  8-8  per  cent,  in  Cootehill  No.  2 Rural,  and  6-8  per  cent,  in  Monaghan  Rural  to  4-2  per  cent,
in  Carrickmacross  Rural,  and  4-4  per  cent,  in  Clones  No.  1 Rural.

Families  and  Houses  (Table  VIII.). — The  number  of  distinct  Families  in  the  County  at  the  time  of  the
late  enumeration  was  16,377,  the  average  number  of  persons  in  a family  being  thus  4-3.  The  number  of
Inhabited  Houses  was  16,307,  showing  an  average  of  4-3  persons  to  each  house.  In  calculating  these
averages  the  Special  Inmates  of  Public  Institutions  have  been  omitted.

Occupiers  of  less  than  5 Rooms  (Tables  IX.,  X.). — The  number  of  Occupiers  (or  Heads  of  Families)
in  occupation  of  less  thanhve  rooms  in  1911  was  12,420,  or  75 '8  per  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families
in  the  County,  and  of  these  591,  or  3-6  per  cent.,  of  the  total  number  of  Families  in  the  County  were
occupiers  of  one  room  ; 3,899  or  23-8  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  two  rooms  ; 5,423,  or  33-1  per  cent.,  occupiers
of  three  rooms  ; and  2,504  or  15 ’3  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  four  rooms.

The  number  of  Tenements  of  One  Room  in  the  County  was  594,  comprising  252  cases  in  which  the
room  had  only  one  occupant ; 268  where  the  room  had  2,  3,  or  4 occupants  ; 66  cases  in  which  there  were-
5,  6,  or  7 occupants  ; and  8 cases  where  the  occupants  exceeded  7 in  number,  including  5 cases  of  8 persons,.
2 cases  of  9 persons,  1 case  of  10  persons  in  the  room.

Civic  Areas.— Towns  having,  in  1911,  a population  of  2,000  and  upwards,  are  classified  as  Civic  Areas.
Ihe  County  contains  three  such  Areas,  viz.,  Carrickmacross,  Clones,  and  Monaghan.  In  1901  the
popuLation  of  these  Areas  amounted  to  8,211.  In  1911  it  was  8,737,  showing  an  increase  of  526
persons,  or  6-4  per  cent.  but  in  the  remainder  of  the  County  there  -vvas  a decrease  of  5'5  per  cent.

Pauperism  (Table  XII.).— TJie  number  of  persons  returned  in  1901  as  receiving  relief  under  the  Poor
I.aw  bl-atera  was  889,  or  one  in  every  84  of  the  population  ; of  this  number  494  were  inmates  of  Workhouses,
and  395  were  in  receipt  of  Outdoor  Relief.  lu  1911  the  number  returned  was  665,  or  one  in  every  107
of  the  population  ; 461  of  these  being  in  the  Workhouses,  and  204  on  Outdoor  Relief,  which  figure
includes  13  children  Boarded-ont,  and  4 in  Certified  Schools.


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


COUNTY  OF  MONAGHAN.


VII.


ThP  Sick  fTable  XII.). — In  1901  the  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Monagium  returned  as  Sick,
(.1,..  r&gt;ioht  of  the  Census,  was  484,  or  one  in  every  154  of  the  population.  In  1911  the  number  so  returned

478  or  one  in  every  149  of  the  population  ; of  the  latter  number  278  were  at  their  own  homes,  and
200  were  in  hospital.

Marriaffes  Bifths,  and  Deaths  (Table  XIV.).— For  the  Piu-poses  of  Registration  of  Births,  Deaths,  and
Maiviao-es  the  Poor  Law'  Union  forms  a “ Superintendent  Registrar’s  District.”  Each  I^ion  or  Superintendent
p^cristtar’s  District  is  divided  into  Dispensary  Districts  for  the  Medical  Relief  of  the  Poor  under  the  Medical
fihfrities  Act:  these  Dispensary  Districts,  save  in  a few  instances,  are  identical  with  ^_e  Registrars
Districts  Each  Dispensary  District  is  composed  of  a certain  number  of  District  Electoral  Divisions.

Arrordine  to  the  returns  of  the  Registrar-General,  the  number  of  Marriages  registered  in  the  County
Afonavlian  durin"  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  1911,  was  3,554,  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate
of  4'9  pel'  1.000  oi  population.  The  number  registered  in  the  whole  of  Ireland  dunng  the  same
period  afiords’an  average  annual  rate  of  5’1  per  1,000.

The  number  of  Births  registered  iu  the  County  during  the  ten  years  was  14,617,  affording  an  average
annual  rate  of  20-0  per  1,000  of  the  population,  the  average  yearly  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  during
the  same  period  being  23  1 per  1,000.

The  Deaths  registered  during  the  decennium  amounted  to  13,580,  being  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate
of  18'6  per  1,000 ; the  corresponding  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  was  17-3  per  1,000.


Birthplaces  of  the  Inhabitants  (Table  XXV.).-Of  the  persons  enumerated  lu  the  County  m 1911,  87-2
nercent  were  born  therein;  8-2  per  cent,  in  other  Counties  of  the  Province  of  Ulster ; 2-0  per  cent,
in  Leinster;  0-3  per  cent,  in  Munster;  0-5  per  cent,  m Connaught;  1-4  per  cent,  in  Great  Bntain ,
and  0-4  per  cent,  were  born  abroad.


Religious  Professions  (Table  XXIX.).— The  foUowing  Statement  shows,  according  to  Religious  Professions,

COUNTY  OF  MONAGHAN.


Irish  Speaking  Population  (Tables  XXXVI.  and  XXXVII.).— The  number  of  persons  in  the  CounH-
Monaghan  returned  as  being  able  to  speak  the  Irish  Language  in  1911  was  5,430,  representine  7 a'
cent,  of  the  total  population  of  the  County.  ” °

Table  XXXVI.  gives  for  the  first  time,  by  District  Electoral  Divisions,  the  information  availahl.
regarding  the  Irish  Speaking  portion  of  the  population  ; while  Table  XXXVII.  shows,  by  County  Distivt?
the  numbers  in  1911,  as  compared  with  those  returned  in  1901.  ' ’

returned  (for  week  ending  13th  May),  was  10,601.  •i’-imber

females) ; the  number  for  the  decade  ending  31st  March,  1901,  was  5,301  • for  that  eudina  wit),  VA  1

prices,

2.  Hydrographical  Publications  of  the  Admiralty  are  sold  by—

J.  D.  PoTTBB,  145,  Miuories,  London,  E.C.

3.  Patent  Office  Publications  am  sold  at—

The  Patent  Office,  25,  Southampton  Buildings,  Chauoery  Lane,  London,  W.C.

(N.B. — Classified  Abri  IgmonU  of  Patent  Spooifications  are  sold  also  by  Wyman  and  Sons,  Ltd.)

4.  Ordnance  Survey  and  Geological  Survey  Publications  can  be  purchased  from—

The  Director  General  of  the  Ordnance  Survey,  Southampton  ; or
The  Superintendent,  Ordnance  Survey,  Dubliu  ; or
Agents  in  most  of  the  chief  towns  in  the  United  Kingdom.

image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


CENSUS  OF  lEELAND,  1911.


COUNTY  OF  TYRONE.


In  addition  to  the  information  contamed  in  the  County  Tables,  it  has  been  deemed  advisable  to  adopt  the
course  pursued  in  previous  Censuses,  and  give  the  following  Summary  of  the  results  obtained  respecting  the
(Administrative)  County  of  Tyrone  from  the  Census  Returns  of  1911.

SUMMARY.

Area.— The  (Admin'istrative)  County  of  Tyrone  covers  an  area  of  806,919  statute  acres,  or  3'9  per
cent,  of  the  total  area  of  the  country.

Population  (Table  II.). — The  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Tyrone,  according  to  the  Census
of  1901,  was  150,567  ; and  according  to  the  recent  Census,  142,665  (71,738  Males  and  70,927  Females),  or
5 '25  per  cent,  less  than  in  1901.

County  Districts  (Table  VI.). — The  following  Statement  shows,  by  County  Districts  (as  constituted
under  the  Local  Government  (Ireland)  Act,  1898).  the  number  of  persons  in  1901  and  1911,  and  the  increase
or  decrease  during  the  decade  : —


County  Districts.

Populatiun.

Increase  or  Decrease
between  1901  and  1911.

1901.

1911.

• Formerly  IiTineatowa  No.  2.'


From  the  foregoing  Statement  it  will  be  observed  that  there  was  an  increase  in  four  County  Districts,
viz.,  1-3  per  cent,  in  Cookstown  Urban,  3-6per  cent,  in  Dungannon  Urban,  1-0  per  cent,  in  Omagh
Urban,  and  1-5  per  cent,  in  Strabane  Urban ; but  a decrease  in  7 County  Districts,  ranging  from  9 '7  per
cent,  in  Trillick  Rm-al,  and  8'5  per  cent,  in  Dungannon  Rural  to  4’0  per  cent,  in  Clogher  Rural,  and  4'1
per  cent,  in  Strabane  No.  1 Rural.

Families  and  Houses  (Table  VIII.). — The  number  of  distinct  Families  in  the  County  at  the  time  of  the
late  enumeration  was  32,340,  the  average  number  of  persons  in  a family  being  thus  4 '4.  The  number  of
Inhabited  Houses  was  32,190,  showing  an  average  of  4 ' 4 persons  to  each  house.  In  calculating  these  averages
the  Special  Inmates  of  Public  Institutions  have  been  omitted.

Occupiers  of  less  than  5 Rooms  (Tables  IX.,  X.). — The  number  of  Occupiers  (or  Heads  of  Families)
in  occupation  of  less  than  five  rooms  in  1911  was  23,837,  or  73' 7 per  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families
in  the  County;  and  of  these  1,348,  or  4'2  per  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families  in  the  County,
were  occupiers  of’ one  room-;  8,613,  or  26  6 per  cent.,  occupiers  of  two  rooms;  8,571,  or  26'5  per  cent.,
occupiers  of  three  rooms  ; and  5,305,  or  16'4  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  four  rooms.

The  number  of  Tenements  of  One  Room  in  the  County  was  1,348,  comprising  509  cases,  in  which  the
room  had  only  one  occupant ; 617  where  the  room  had  2,  3,  or  4 occupants  ; 180  cases  in  which  there  were
5,  6,  or  7 occupants ; and  42  cases  where  the  occupants  exceeded  7 in  number,  including  5 cases  of  10
persons,  2 cases  of  11  persons,  and  2 of  12  or  more  persons  in  the  room.

Civic  Areas. — Towns  having,  in  1911,  a population  of  2,000  and  upwards,  are  classified  as  Civic  Areas.
The  County  contains  four  such  Areas,  viz.,  Cookstown,  Dungannon,  Omagh  and  Strabane.  In  1901  the
population  of  these  Areas  amounted  to  17,155.  In  1911  it  was  17,458,  showing  an  increase  of  303
persons,  or  1'8  per  cent.  ; but  in  remainder  of  the  County  there  was  a decrease  of  6' 2 per  cent.

Pauperism  (Table  XII.). — The  number  of  persons  returned  in  1901  as  receiving  relief  under  the  Poor
Law  System  was  1,841,  or  one  in  every  82  of  the  population  ; of  this  number  875  -were  inmates  of  Workhouses,
and  966  were  in  receipt  of  Outdoor  Relief.  In  1911  the  number  returned  was  1,329,  or  one  in  every  107  of
the  population  ; 738  of  these  being  in  the  Workhouses,  and  591  on  Outdoor  Relief,  which  figure  includes  40
children  Boarded-out.


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


COUNTY  OF  TYRONE.


Vll.


The  Sick  (Table  XII.). — In  1901  the  number  of  persons  in  the  County  of  Tyrone  returned  as  Sick,
on  the  night  of  the  Census,  was  982,  or  one  in  every  153  of  the  population.  In  1911  the  number  so  returned
was  783,  or  one  in  every  182  of  the  population  ; of  the  latter  number  481  were  at  their  own  homes,  and  302
were  in  hospital.

Marriages,  Births,  and  Deaths  (Table  XIV.). — For  the  purposes  of  Eegistration  of  Births,  Deaths,  and
jMarriages,  the  Poor  Law  Union  forms  a “ Superintendent  Registrar’s  District.”  Each  Union  or  Superintendent
Registrar’s  District  is  divided  into  Dispensary  Districts  for  the  Medical  Relief  of  the  Poor  under  the  Medical
Charities  Act ; these  Dispensary  Districts,  save  in  a few  instances,  are  identical  with  the  Registrars’  Districts.
Each  Dispensary  District  is  composed  of  a certain  number  of  District  Electoral  Divisions.

According  to  the  returns  of  the  Registrar-General,  the  number  of  marriages  registered  in  the  County  of
TjTone  during  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  1911,  was  7,288,  equal  to  an  average  annual  rate  of  5'0
per  1,000  of  the  population.  The  number  registered  in  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the  same  period  aSords
an  average  annual  rate  of  5'1  per  1,000.

The  number  of  Bii-ths  registered  in  the  County  during  the  ten  years  was  30,094,  affording  an  average
annual  rate  of  20 '5  per  1,000  of  the  population,  the  average  yearly  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  during  the
same  period  being  23 ‘1  per  1,000.

The  Deaths  registered  during  the  deoennium  amounted  to  26,663,  being  equal  to  an  average  annnal  rate
of  18'2  per  1,000;  the  corresponding  rate  for  the  whole  of  Ireland  was  17'3  per  1,000,

Birthplaces  ol  the  Inhabitants  (Table  XXV.).— Of  the  persons  enumerated  in  the  County  in  1911,  87-9
per  cent,  were  born  therein ; 8 8 per  cent,  in  other  Counties  of  the  Province  of  Ulster ; 0-6_per  cent,  in
Leinster  ; 0 • 2 per  cent,  in  Munster  ; 0 ' 3 per  cent,  in  Connaught ; 1 • 7 per  cent,  in  Great  Britain  ; and  0 ' 5
per  cent,  were  born  abroad.

Religious  Professions  (Table  XXIX.).— The  following  Statement  shows,  according  to  Religious  Professions,
the  Inhabitants  of  the  County  of  Tyrone  in  1911 : —

From  the  above  Table  it  will  be  seen  that  of  the  total  population  of  the  County  in  1911,  55'4  per  cent,
were  Roman  Catholics ; 22  • 7 per  cent.  Protestant  Episcopalians  ; 18  • 6 per  cent.  Presbyterians ; and  2 • 0 per
cent.  Methodists.  In  1901  Roman  Catholics  formed  54' 7 per  cent. ; Protestant  Episcopalians,  22 '5  per  cent. ;
Presbyterians,  19'7  per  cent. ; and  Methodists,  21  per  cent.,  of  the  population  of  the  County.

Education  (Tables  XXX.  and  XXXIII.). — In  reckoning  the  number  of  illiterates,  the  age  of  9 years
has  now  been  substituted  for  the  age  of  5,  which  was  formerly  adopted.

On  this  basis  the  details  of  population,  aged  9 years  and  upwards,  for  this  County,  are  : —


—

100-

For  comparative  purposes  the  figures  for  those  between  the  ages  of  5 and  9,  who  can  read  and  write,  are
shown  in  Table  XXX.

It  is  satisfactory  to  note  that  had  the  earlier  age  of  five  been  taken  as  the  starting  point  on  this  occasion,
as  in  former  years,  it  would  have  appeared  that  the  per-centage  of  those  unable  to  read  or  write,  which  was
17-4  in  1891,  and  14-2  in  1901,  had  fallen  to  13'7  in  1911.


Printed  image  digitised  by  the  University  of  Southampton  Library  Digitisation  Unit


COUNTY  OF  TYRONE.


viii.

Irish  Speaking  Population  (Tables  XXXVI.  and  XXXVII.}. — Tlie  number  of  persons  in  the  County  o(
Tyrone  returned  as  being  able  to  speak  the  Irish  Language  in  1911  was  7,584,  representing  5'.3  per  cent
of  the  total  population  of  the  County.

Table  XXXVI.  gives  for  the  first  time,  by  District  Electoral  Divisions,  the  information  available  regarding
the  Irish  Speaking  portion  of  the  population  ; while  Table  XXXVII.  shows,  by  County  Districts,  the  uumbeB
in  1911,  as  compared  with  those  returned  in  1901.

School  Attendance  (Table  XXXVIII.). — The  number  of  pupils  attending  school  in  the  County  of
T}-rone,  according  to  the  Census  of  1901  (week  ending  11th  May),  was  1 7,073.  In  1911  the  number  retiuned
(for  week  ending  13tb  May)  'was  19,956.

Emigration  Table  XLI.). — The  number  of  Emigrants  during  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  1911,
who  stated  that  they  were  from  the  County  of  Tyrone,  amounted  to  10,539  (5,643  males,  and  4,896  females);
the  number  for  the  decade  ending  31st  March.  1901,  was  12,598  ; for  that  ending  with  March,  1891,  28,960 ;
for  that  ftnding  with  March,  18S1,  29,674  ; for  that  ending  with  March,  1871,  23,722,  and  for  that  ending
•with  March,  1861,  39,620,  making  a total  of  145,122,  for  the  sixty  years.


WILLIAM  J.  THOMPSON,

Registrar-GeneTal

EDWARD  O’FARRELL,

DANIEL  S.  DOYLE.

(a.)  The  Gvic  Areas  comprise  all  Municipal  Boroughs,  Urban  Districts,  and  Towns  of  2,000  inhabitants  and  upwards.

Note.— The  plan  of  classification  in  the  foregoing  Table  is  the  same  as  that  adopted  in  former  Censuses,  and  may  be  thus  described

The  value  or  condition  of  a house,  as  to  its  quality,  may  be  considered  to  depend  mainly  on

1st,  Its  extent,  as  shown  by  tlw  number  of  rooms ; 2nd,  its  quality,  as  shown  by  the  number  of  its  irindows,  and  3rd,  its  solidity  or  durability,  asilwi
bhe  material  of  its  walls  and  roof.  If  numbers  be  adopted  to  express  the  position  of  every  house  in  a scale  of  each  of  these  ehad^
and  if  the  numbers  thus  obtabsed  for  every  house  be  added  together,  a new  series  of  numbers  will  be  produced,  givina  the  position  of  esetha
in  a scale  compounded  of  all  the  elements,  their  actual  state.

Four  cl^M  have  been  adopted,  and  the  result  is,  that  in  the  lowest  of  the  four  olnsses  are  comprised  bouses  principally  built  of  mud  or  other  perishable  nwloH
havmg  only  one  room  and  window ; in  the  third  a better  description  of  house,  varying  from  one  to  four  rooms  and  windows ; in  the  second  wlut  otf
be  considered  a good  farm  house,  having  from  five  to  nine  rooms  and  windows;  and  in  the  first  class  all  houses  of  a better  description  tlua &gt;!*
preceding.

The  accommodation  which  the  houses  afford  has  obo  been  arranged  under  four  classes,  viz.

First  Class  accommodation  consisting  of  1st  class  houses,  occupied  fay  one  family.

Second  Class  accomm^ation  consis&amp;g  of  2nd  class  houses,  occupied  hy  one  family,  or  of  1st  class  houses,  occupied  by  two  or  three  families.
Thud  Goss  accommodation  comprising  3rd  class  houses,  with  one  family  each,  or  second  class  houses,  with  two  or  three  families,  or  Ut  class


&gt; better  description  tka


•e  than  one  family,  2nd  class  houses  with  four  oj

EERATA.


Co.  Tyrone. — In  Tables  XV. — XVII.  {pages  63-65),  36  males  and  44  females  under  one  year  have  been
erroneously  included  with  those  of  one  and  under  five  in  the  figures  for  Cookstown.

35  males  and  30  females  have  been  similarly  misplaced  with  regard  to  Dungannon.

The  correct  figures  are  summarised  in  Tables  XV. — XVII.  {pages  9-10)  of  the  Summary  of
the  Province  of  Ulster.

CENSUS  OF  lEELAND,  1911.


PEOVINCE  OF  TJLSTEE.


In  addition  to  the  information  contained  in  the  County  Tables,  it  has  been  deemed  advisable  to  adopt  tie
course  pursued  in  previous  Censuses,  and  give  Summaries  of  the  results  obtained  respecting  the  several
Counties  in  Ulster  from  the  Census  Returns  of  1911  ; similar  information  is  here  given  for  the  Province
together  with  a Synopsis  of  the  County  Summaries.  ’


SUMMARY.

Area. — The  Province  of  Ulster  covers  an  area  of  5,491,485  statute  acres,  or  26 -3  per  cent,  of  the
total  area  of  the  country.

Population  (Table  II.). — The  number  of  persons  in  the  Province  of  Ulster,  according  to  the  Census
of  1901,  was  1,582,826  ; and  according  to  the  recent  Census,  1,581,696  (770,862  Males  and  810,834  Females),
or  0-07  per  cent,  less  than  in  1901.

Counties  and  County  Boroughs  (Table  VI.). — The  following  Statement  shows,  by  Counties  and  County
Boroughs,  (as  constituted  under  the  Local  Government  (Ireland)  Act,  1898),  the  number  of  persons  in  1901
and  1911,  and  the  increase  or  decrease  during  the  decade: —


Population.  I Increase  or  Deoroase

between  1901  and  1911.


Counties  and  County  Boroughs.

1001.

1911.

Rate

Decrease.
