From  the  foregoing  Statement  it  will  be  observed  that  there  was  an  increase  in  each  of  the  County
Boroughs,  viz.,  10'8  per  cent,  in  Belfast,  and  2'2  per  cent,  in  Londonderry  ; but  a decrease  in  each  of  the
Counties,  ranging  from  6'5  per  cent,  in  Cavan  County,  and  5’5  per  cent,  in  Fermanagh  County,  to  0'8  per
cent,  in  Down  County  and  I'l  per  cent,  in  Autrim  County.

Families  ^d  Houses  (Table  VIII.). — The  number  of  distinct  Families  in  the  Province  at  the  time  of  the
late  enumeration  was  340,431,  the  average  number  of  persons  in  a family  being  thus  4-6.  The  number  of
Inhabited  Houses  was  335,511,  showing  an  average  of  4' 6 persons  to  each  house.  In  calculating  these
averages  the  Special  Inmates  of  Public  Institutions  have  been  omitted.

Occupiers  of  less  than  5 Rooms  (Tables  IX.,  X.). — The  number  of  Occupiers  (or  Heads  of  Families)
in  occupation  of  less  than  five  rooms  in  1911  was  209,372,  or  61  • 5 per  cent,  of  the  total  number  of  Families
in  the  Province,  and  of  these  28  were  occupiers  of  part  of  a room  only;  10,847,  or  3-2  per  cent.,  of  the  total
number  of  Families  in  the  Province  were  occupiers  of  one  room  ; 66,773  or  19  • 6 per  cent.,  occupiers  of  two
rooms  ; 69,508,  or  20-4  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  three  rooms  ; and  62,216,  or  18'3  per  cent.,  occupiers  of  fotu'
rooms.

The  number  of  Tenements  of  One  Room  in  the  Province  was  10,861,  comprising  4,182  cases  in  which  ths
room  had  only  one  occupant ; 4,964  where  the  room  had  2,  3,  or  4 occupants ; 1,404  cases  in  which  there  were
5,  6,  or  7 occupants ; and  311  cases  where  the  occupants  ezceeded  7 in  number,  including  38  cases  of  10
persons,  10  cases  of  11  persons,  and  6 cases  of  12  or  more  persons  in  the  room.

Civic  Areas. — Towns  having,  in  1911,  a population  of  2,000  and  upwards,  are  classified  as  Civic  Areas.
The  Province  contains  36  such  Areas.  In  1901  the  population  of  these  Areas  amounted  to  557,078.
In  1911  it  was  607,002,  showing  an  increase  of  49,924  persons,  or  9'0  per  cent.  ; but  in  the  remaioder
of  the  Province  there  was  a decrease  of  5-0  per  cent.

Pauperism  (Table  XII.).  The  number  of  persons  returned  in  1901  as  receiving  relief  under  the
Law  System  was  18,463,  or  one  in  every  86  of  the  population  ; of  this  number  9,551  were  inmates  of  Work-
houses,  and  8,912  were  in  receipt  of  Outdoor  Relief.  In  1911  the  number  returned  was  15,113,  or  one
every  105  of  the  population ; 8,883  of  these  being  in  the  Workhouses,  and  6,230  on  Outdoor  Belief,
which  figure  includes  537  children  Boarded-out,  and  17  in  Certified  Schools.

Religious  Prolessions  (Table  XXlX.l.-Tbo  following  Statement  shows,  according  to  Eeligious  Professions,
the  Inhabitants  of  the  Province  of  Ulster  in  1911 :—

From  the  above  Table  it  will  be  seen  that  of  the  total  population  of  the  Province  in  1911,  43  7 per  cent,
were  Roman  Catholics ; 23‘2  per  cent.  Protestant  Episcopalians ; 26^6  per  cent.  Presbyterians  , and  3 1 per
cent.  Methodists.  In  1901  Roman  Catholics  formed  44-2  per  cent. ; Protestant  Episcopalmns,  22  8 pei  cent.
Presbyterians,  26 ‘9  per  cent. ; and  Methodists,  3-0  per  cent.,  of  the  population  of  the  Provmce.


Education  (Tables  XXX.  and  XXXni.).-In  reckoning  the  number  of  illiterates  the  age  of  9 years  Las
• been  substituted  for  the  age  of  5,  which  was  formerly  adopted.

On  this  basis  the  details  of  population,  aged  9 years  and  upwards,  for  this  Province  are

For  comparative  purposes  the  figures  for  those  between  the  ages  of  5 and  9,  who  can  read  and  write,  are
shoa-n  in  Table  XXX.


It  is  satisfactory  to  note  that  had  the  earlier  age  of  five  been  taken  as  the  starting  point  on  this  occasion
as  in  former  years,  it  would  have  appeared  that  the  per-centage  of  those  unable  to  read  or  write,  which  was
15-4  in  1891,  and  12-5  in  1901,  had  fallen  to  11-5  in  1911.

PROVINCE  OF  ULSTER.


viii


Irish  Speaking  Population  {Table  XXXVII.).— The  number  of  persons  in  the  Pi'ovince  of  Ulste
returned  as  being  able  to  speak  the  Irish  Language  in  1911  was  96,440,  representing  6T  per  cen/
of  the  total  population  of  the  Province.  Of  these  4,737  could  speak  “ Irish  only,”  and  91,703  could  sueal,.'
Irish  and  English.  ^

School  Attendance  (Table  XXXVIII.) — The  number  of  pupils  attending  school  in  the  Province  of
Ulster,  according  to  the  Census  of  1901  (week  ending  11th  May),  was  225,701.  In  1911  the  number
returned  (for  week  ending  13th  May),  was  245,381.

Emigration  (Table  XLI.).— The  number  of  Emigrants  during  the  ten  years  ending  31st  March,  191]
who  stated  that  they  were  from  the  Province  of  Ulster,  amounted  to  106,587  (68,298  male’s,  and
48,289  females) ; the  number  for  the  decade  ending  31st  March,  1901,  was  86,455  ; for  that  ending’  with
March,  1891,216,524;  for  that  ending  with  March,  1881,  240,110;  for  that  ending  with  March,  1871
201,240,  and  for  that  ending  with  March,  1861,  341,261,  making  a total  of  1,192,177  for  the  sixty  years.  ’

  archive_analytics.send_pageview_on_load(archive_analytics);
  archive_analytics.process_url_events(location);
  var vs = archive_analytics.get_data_packets();
  for (var i in vs) {
    if (!vs[i]) {
      vs[i] = {};
    }
    vs[i]['cache_bust']=Math.random();
    vs[i]['server_ms']=124;
    vs[i]['server_name']="www29.us.archive.org";

    archive_analytics.send_scroll_fetch_base_event();
  }
}
